content: Hi, I'm a civilian. One aspect of the military that fascinates me is that many wide-eyed 18 year-olds who have never ventured far from their home town interact with others across the country, and then travel abroad, learning about other cultures, etc. A friend has said the most obnoxious people come from New York and Texas. There are obnoxious people everywhere, but does this comport with personal experiences? Another has said, "Ah, Texans. Did you know they will draw the lone star state on anything? They will!" From personal, non-military experiences, this is not super-surprising. People from Texas and New York seem to have strong identities connected to their states. "I'm tough, I grew up in the Bronx." I'd say the same seems true for people with a Southern Heritage, which can be jarring to people here on the West Coast, which seems a little more laid back (except in Southern California, where location-status is significantly more intense). Anyway, Texas and New York. Is that an unfair characterization? I'm not trying to start a flame war or peddle nasty stereotypes, but... does that kinda hold up?

content: I'm from Texas... and WTF do you mean we're obnoxious?!? "They will draw the lone star state on anything?" Well I don't know what kind of Texans you've been runnin' into, but true Texans, as in grew up in the boonies ridin' horses and ranchin' cattle, don't draw on things other than paper... we say ma'am and sir and are a hoot to have a few beers with... but don't come talkin' sheet or you'll wind up on your rear-end on the ground. Obnoxious... ha! Maybe some of these "young bucks" that think they're hot stuff, but TRUE Texans are nothin' of the sort. Them damned Yankees though....

content: i have lived in both places and yu may be half-right. Spent about a year in san antonio and wichita falls, texas, i never found Texans to be obnoxious at all, at least not any more than anywhere else. Alot of them are very proud of being Texan and see themselves as being a bit more independent than those from the other 49 states, and there is nothing wrong with that. Many residents of New York city on the other hand, can be very obnoxious, rude, and inconsiderate and perhaps it rubs off onto each other more than anyplace else.

content: Hi, I'm a civilian. One aspect of the military that fascinates me is that many wide-eyed 18 year-olds who have never ventured far from their home town interact with others across the country, and then travel abroad, learning about other cultures, etc. A friend has said the most obnoxious people come from New York and Texas. There are obnoxious people everywhere, but does this comport with personal experiences? Another has said, "Ah, Texans. Did you know they will draw the lone star state on anything? They will!" From personal, non-military experiences, this is not super-surprising. People from Texas and New York seem to have strong identities connected to their states. "I'm tough, I grew up in the Bronx." I'd say the same seems true for people with a Southern Heritage, which can be jarring to people here on the West Coast, which seems a little more laid back (except in Southern California, where location-status is significantly more intense). Anyway, Texas and New York. Is that an unfair characterization? I'm not trying to start a flame war or peddle nasty stereotypes, but... does that kinda hold up?

content: Hi, I'm a civilian. One aspect of the military that fascinates me is that many wide-eyed 18 year-olds who have never ventured far from their home town interact with others across the country, and then travel abroad, learning about other cultures, etc. A friend has said the most obnoxious people come from New York and Texas. There are obnoxious people everywhere, but does this comport with personal experiences? Another has said, "Ah, Texans. Did you know they will draw the lone star state on anything? They will!" From personal, non-military experiences, this is not super-surprising. People from Texas and New York seem to have strong identities connected to their states. "I'm tough, I grew up in the Bronx." I'd say the same seems true for people with a Southern Heritage, which can be jarring to people here on the West Coast, which seems a little more laid back (except in Southern California, where location-status is significantly more intense). Anyway, Texas and New York. Is that an unfair characterization? I'm not trying to start a flame war or peddle nasty stereotypes, but... does that kinda hold up?
